title: This is a disgusting excuse for an Olaf, Riot. (Jinx PBE changes)
body:
Yea, I know these probably won't go through, and rightfully so.  But it's disgustingly pitiful that they even made it onto the PBE in the first place.

Jinx is a very balanced ADC, supporting a feast or famine(until 45 minutes) playstyle.  This is good and showcases her weaknesses, while exemplifying her strengths.  She's a late game hyper-carry that can eat towers and enemy champions.  This is why I love her!  I have 124 Ranked games with Jinx this season alone, and while I know there are some with far more, she is far and away my preferred champion of choice as a Gold 2 ADC main.  

She's bogged down with her own problems already.  Her Zap doesn't do anywhere close to the damage it originally did, and while that's not that big of an issue, it sure does hurt her laning.  But far more than that, her chompers take so long to proc that most people run clean over them without getting hit at all.  And now you put these nerfs on the PBE?

Jinx

! (R) minimum damage decreased to 25/35/45 from 125/175/225
! (R) minimum AD ratio reduced to .1 AD from .5 AD 


Are you kidding me?  You're nerfing her ult's damage by 100/140/180 damage at the three ranks, then reducing the AD ratio to .1?  Is this a joke?  It's a SUPER MEGA DEATH ROCKET, not one of Heimer's toy wrenches.  What's the point of even shooting the ult now when my autos do more damage than this?  Who pushed these to PBE?  How did they get through internal testing?  I thought we learned from Olaf, Veigar, and others that gutting a champion isn't the way to go.  You're taking away all damage from her ultimate, HER ULTIMATE, with no compensation anywhere.  I mineaswell start practicing my Kog'Maw because Jinx will have 3 abilities after this nerf.


I know that these probably won't ever hit Live.  I know that the PBE is used for testing.  But to know that these were even considered and that they made it all the way to PBE is just...it makes me question whoever thought it would be a good idea at Riot.  When Jinx was released, all I heard from Riot was how much they loved her and the amount of work they put into her, including the music video and website teasers.  Riot said there probably would never be a champion that stole the heart of so many Rioters ever again.  And yet here I am, looking at these nerfs and wondering what the heck happened.  Because someone obviously never wants her to be played again.


That's my rant.  Yes, I'm frustrated.  Yes, I know it's PBE.  But when my main champion has a gutting nerf on PBE, I'm going to complain at the only place I know I can and just hope that it changes someone's mind.  I don't have access to the PBE boards so this is the only place I can do that.  

Thank you for your time.

replies.body:
AFKAKDSFKJSDFA...I just spent an hour typing up a long detailed response to this and then my computer ate it.  whyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy I'm so sad right now...

Give me some time to retype it.  I'll be back.

Okay got response typed up again.

So as Jinx's designer I asked to head up the nerfs coming out for her this patch.  Let's talk about them and Jinxy in general.

First full info on the nerfs:
The **min** damage on the R is being cut.  The **max** damage is staying the same.  Additionally, the execute damage is not being touched.  **SMD rocket will ALWAYS deal 25/30/35% of the target's missing health regardless of range.**

Below are the rough damage estimates based on ranges Jinxs should be familiar with:

*NUMBERS AND CHANGES ARE SUBJECT TO CHANGE (or not).  ALL THIS IS STILL IN TESTING*

R damage @ Point blank:** 125/175/225(+.5) >>> 25/35/45 (+.1) **

R damage @ Minigun range: **175/245/315 (+.7) >>> 110/155/200(+.45)**

R damage @ Level 9 Rocket range: **185/260/335 (+.75) >>>  135/190/245(+.55)**

R damage @ Shock Pistol range (max): **unchanged - 250/350/450(+1.0)**

**TLDR summary of the below wall of text:
We like Jinx being strong for a variety of reasons but she may be TOO strong at the moment. Jinx's snowballing and hyper-carry potential is intended to be strong and we like it where it is so this change is targeted at amping up her main weakness (gets wrekt if jumped on).  IF THIS CHANGE GOES TOO FAR WE'LL FOLLOW UP ON IT.  THE GOAL HERE IS A SLIGHT TONING DOWN OF JINX'S POWER.
**

Generally we like Jinx being a strong champ in League of Legends. Even when winning she has a lot of inbuilt counterplay which makes losing to her feel a lot less demoralizing.  Thanks to her general immobility combined with the delayed and conditional nature of her spells players tend to come out of games against Jinx with gameplans on how they're going to beat her next time.

Going off of this, it is likely that Jinx "at balance" sits at above a 50% winrate.  This partially stems from the nature of her power profile. Jinx is highly snowbally, especially in AoE focused teamfights, and is one of the best characters in the game at taking objectives after killing off the enemy team. This is going to contribute to a higher number of wins in solo queue where the "group and push" strategy is so prevalent (Jinx loves grouping and pushing!).  People group, teamfights happen, Jinx AoE's things, and 1 kill tends to lead to 1-4 more + towers and dragons.

Additionally, it's worth mentioning Jinx's dedicated player base. If you run into a Jinx player on live that person is going to have 31 games on her on average,  That's up there with other "I main dis guy forever" champs like Yasuo, Lee Sin, and Riven.  For comparison, Graves has a similar play rate to Jinx (they're neck and neck for most picked ADC), and yet the average Graves player only has 16 games on him.  This isn't meant to be a knock on Graves but more a highlight on the fact that many of the Jinx's you run into out there have played her A LOT and as such you'd expect a higher win rate out of her due to player experience.

So I've gone over why we're okay with Jinx being strong so in that case why are we nerfing her? Well the thing is there's strong and then there's I AM THE GOD OF SOLO QUEUE strong.  Jinx is trending towards the latter and has only been getting better each patch.  She's got one of the highest winrates in the game at 55% across all elos and that combined with her insane playrate is cause for alarm. We felt some light tuning would be appropriate to level the playing field vs. other ADC's so we looked across her kit and asked ourselves "is there anything Jinx is doing right now that maybe she shouldn't be?"

So as her designer I've always felt that Jinx is defined by the following strength and weakness
**A) Jinx is a snowball:** If you let Jinx get ahead and can't figure out how to get to her SHE WILL TAKE EVERYTHING YOU LOVE AND BURN IT TO THE GROUND.
**B) Jinx has a hard time with people who invade her personal space.**  If you manage to jump on her when she's unprepared you should be rewarded accordingly.

The strength is supported by things like Get Excited (the speed passive), the always-on AS/range+AoE steroids on Switcheroo (the Q), and Jinx's reach in general which progresses from 525 range - to 700 - to 1500 - to global.  This power combination ensures that if Jinx has enough gold and manages to get a foothold of safety/advantage in a fight she WILL GET TO YOU, BLOW YOU UP, AND THEN TAKE YOUR TOWERS.  This is good, it's character defining and it's what we'd like her to excel at.

The weakness is supported by the ramp up on minigun, the cast/arm times on all her spells/ and the damage w/distance mechanic on the R.  If you manage to close with an unprepared Jinx she's going to have a hard time dealing with you.  Her spells leave her vulnerable, her AS needs to ramp for full DPS, chompers take a while to arm, **and ideally she can't just Graves ult you for a burst of power unless you're incredibly low on health.  **
^^^^^that last thing is where we found a possible problem. Jinx was winning a number of engagements off the sheer burst power of her ultimate, even at pointblank range.  This to me is out of line with her strength/weakness profile. 

In summary:
**Jinx is a hyper carry who can kill every single member of your team from extreme ranges if left alone but if you jump on her she should be at a severe disadvantage. ** Nerfing the pointblank ultimate makes the weakness more true and allows us to preserve her strengths in light of extreme power in solo queue.

If I'm in a 1v1 engagement and people are jumping on me, but I get them low, I should be able to blow them up with  Super Mega DEATH Rocket.  I shouldn't be punished for them jumping on top of me.  I already have enough problems when they're there.  Yea, I have my execute still, but if there's no base damage to back it up, it seems like it won't matter.  It'll be a waste for me to even try to launch the spell.

And you're also only looking at when she gets jumped on.  What about when she's in lane and gets a gank and there are two low players running away down their lane.  I'll no longer be able to snipe them because it's not going to ramp up in time.  In fact, it encourages players to run closer to the rocket so that it does the 25 damage instead of the med/max damage possibilities.  After 1 second, it's back to normal, but that 1 second is a long time, especially when trying to hit a champ that's nearby that may be low.  

I understand your view, and you're obviously the designer so I can't argue with how you perceive Jinx and what she is.  In fact, I think you hit on a lot of things that are very true.  But you said it yourself.  Jinx has a very dedicated playerbase and we play her a lot.  There should be a higher than average win rate when those playing her almost always consider her their main.  So trying to take solo queue win rate into it is a poor choice.  If this was someone that didn't have as loyal a playerbase, that's one thing.  But when you even admit that they average Jinx player in Ranked has 31+ games on her, there's a reason she's winning.

I don't know how many times I've been tower dove as Jinx and had three people on top of me.  I flash away and put out some Fishbones on them to see them get fairly low.  I'm then able to fire my SMDR from point blank and pick up a double or triple kill because of enemies' overagression.  That won't be possible with these nerfs.  They'll just laugh at my squeaky toy flying at them.


gypsylord, I respect your work and your design for Jinx and other champs, so I'm going to ask you this and I hope for a response.  You've played (I sure hope you've played) this nerfed version of Jinx.  Do you believe it impacts her playstyle?  Will she lose those close trades that she might normally win because of this?

And lastly, let's say we're in a normal laning situation.  I've got a B.F. Sword and Doran's Blade.  I get dove onto and the enemies get low, making me fire off my SMDR onto them.  Let's say we're level 7.  How much health is the enemy going to need to be at for me to land a kill?


I understand your desire to make her a little less overbearing and crazy, but she's got a doctor's note man!  Cutting the minimum damage by 100/140/180 seems way over the top for any nerf.  My tier 3 isn't even as strong as my tier 1.  Jinx has only ever received nerfs since her release, whether it was her W, her E, or her Q.  This just seems a bit overboard.

> [{quoted}](name=FatedTitan,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BiL98QHi,comment-id=000700050005,timestamp=2015-04-22T02:27:05.758+0000)
>
> If I'm in a 1v1 engagement and people are jumping on me, but I get them low, I should be able to blow them up with  Super Mega DEATH Rocket.  **I shouldn't be punished for them jumping on top of me. ** I already have enough problems when they're there. 

Actually, yes, you should. That's the entire point that Gypsylord was making. Jinx has good range, and does insane damage at range. Somebody getting in her face is supposed to be her weakness, and thus if your positioning is off too much that you allow them to get on top of you, _you should be punished for it._

Dives under tower don't mean you're out of position.  It means you got dove.  Period.  

We're in a League of Tanks that can jump on me freely and deal 3/4 of my damage in 1/2 a cycle of spells.  And they want to nerf me more?

"jumping on top of me" is not ALWAYS a tower dive. If you are in the middle of the lane and get jumped, you should die. 

And if a tank jumps you under tower, Jinx has OTHER ways to deal with it. Use chompers to cut of their escape route. Better yet, put chompers JUST behind them, so they have a choice: Run now and you can get out before they arm, and follow me and be committed to staying under tower. 

Not to mention, Jinx's "power profile" SHOULD NOT favor her on the defensive, she is a pushing/siege-ing powerhouse, and she should not excel at defending towers against tanks. LoL is no longer a game entirely dictated by the ADC's power as it used to be. Jinx will be dived by tanks and killed. Corkis will be forced to run away. Contrast this to Vayne, who is the optimal tank-shredder, and would not be likely to be dived and lose. But Vayne does not have the range to handle people like Jinx, nor does she have the burst that Graves has, or the mid-game power of Corki. ADC's are not longer the cure-all to the issue of the enemy team. Rather, they have inherent strengths and weaknesses as they should have for a long time. 

As for the League of Tanks comment, tanks are a bit of the flavor of the month. They are strong because no one has had to deal with a truly strong tank in a while. Yes, cinderhulk might be a bit on the strong side, but even disregarding that, strong pushing ADCs such as Jinx and Sivir have high winrates. This indicates a main weakness of a tank: They do best when they are the ones initiating. In soloQ, half of the fights fought a lost or one by which side initiates first and with more confidence. Tanks are not good on defense.

You're mainly going to feel it against people in melee range of you (and that's the point) but in the average lane duel at 525 + range it should still be a potent execute.  In the early game you're likely going to need one more basic attack than before to secure those closer range kills.

I'm also willing to admit that we're not omniscient and this change may affect her in ways we didn't anticipate. We'll follow up on it if that's the case.

In the early game you're likely going to need one more basic attack than before to secure those closer range kills.

> I'm also willing to admit that we're not omniscient and this change may affect her in ways we didn't anticipate. **We'll follow up on it if that's the case.**

I take some issue with the phrase i've bolded. After changes, Riot always said "we'll follow up if need be." but honestly, the followup time to absolute gutting of champions is awful. Look at the Cass rework as an example, or even Skarner. It takes months, after a drastic change, to bring champions back in line. No offense gypsylord, especially because you've done some pretty fine balancing, but the followup time is trash, and really only discourages me from having faith in the balancing of champions.

Edit: Or Olaf, or Elise, or Veigar, the list goes on...

That is because following up takes time. You need to decide on a new direction for changes. Given how much gypsylord went through to decide on this nerf that could be a significant length of time particularly if some ideas have already been rejected because they didn't work.

Look at the Cass rework. No sudden moves were made, discussions were had changes were made. 
The Skarner rework needed a lot more than the Cassiopeia one did. Take a look at reworked champion timelines - they are in production for months. Skarner effectively needed a second rework and so it would be foolish to expect that to take anything less than months unless you want a half arsed job.

You also want to leave some time for players to relearn their favourite champion - some of the changes are significant. Obviously people are going to lose more than they did a week ago (if they didn't it would be a problem). These losses are likely to negatively affect the opinion of players about the rework.

This Jinx nerf is fairly small in the grand scheme of things. How do you have to change your play to make Jinx work just as well? You will probably have to play more safely in lane because ganks and dives will be more dangerous. You will have to be even more careful with your chompers. Perhaps you will need to poke more so that their dives become riskier. Late game you will have to position yourself even better than you currently do. 

It takes time for people to adapt to these things and making hasty changes to a champion before this happens could lead to some awful things.

> [{quoted}](name=qetzel,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BiL98QHi,comment-id=000700050005000300000001,timestamp=2015-04-22T10:13:38.887+0000)
>

> 
> Look at the Cass rework. No sudden moves were made, discussions were had changes were made. 

No sudden moves were made? Are you high? The Cass rework was on PBE for less than 2 weeks before it got pushed to live, even after countless players pointed out how undertuned and unfulfilled the kit felt. Please, don't say Cass wasn't rushed because you're going to lose legitimacy in this dialogue by doing so.

> The Skarner rework needed a lot more than the Cassiopeia one did. Take a look at reworked champion timelines - they are in production for months. Skarner effectively needed a second rework and so it would be foolish to expect that to take anything less than months unless you want a half arsed job.
> 
> You also want to leave some time for players to relearn their favourite champion - some of the changes are significant. Obviously people are going to lose more than they did a week ago (if they didn't it would be a problem). These losses are likely to negatively affect the opinion of players about the rework.

This is Riot's usual go-to when saying "we need time to assess the impact" but let's be frank here. Not all changes need time to adjust to, most changes are immediately noticeable in ways that dedicated X-mains can tell you about, sometimes without even testing. As a Morgana main, I can tell you that any nerf to her puddle, even 5 damage per tick, would be enough to make her nigh-unplayable in midlane. I don't need to play her more than a game to tell you that result. Number changes are the easiest to tell if something is too-far in one direction, and this is one of those instances where the numbers have been pushed way too far in one direction.

At the end of the day this is about follow-up time, not whether or not these nerfs are too far or not far enough to bring Jinx back in line. Riot has had a LONG history of letting champions sit in obscurity after nerfs, or letting champions dominate for months after buffs. They aren't consistent with how quickly the follow-up on changes. With that being said, it is perfectly fair-game to point that out to gypsylord, because his definition of follow-up may be 3 months from now, or maybe its on the next PBE patch, or even the next patch to go live. And because there is no guarantee for it to be *any* of those, the point of follow-up times being trash still stands.

I said that the changes to the rework weren't rushed. We are discussing follow up to work, not the original work.

> This is Riot's usual go-to when saying "we need time to assess the impact" but let's be frank here. Not all changes need time to adjust to, most changes are immediately noticeable in ways that dedicated X-mains can tell you about, sometimes without even testing. I don't need to play her more than a game to tell you that result. Number changes are the easiest to tell if something is too-far in one direction, and this is one of those instances where the numbers have been pushed way too far in one direction.
> 

Your Morgana example is slightly different in that that is a nerf to both her best case and worst case situations. It is also not a change designed to punish bad play or reward opponents good play. It is just a numbers thing. 

The numbers in this situation haven't been changed that much. Only at really low ranges is the damage change significant, and given Jinx's high range she doesn't need as much short range damage.

>Riot has had a LONG history of letting champions sit in obscurity after nerfs, or letting champions dominate for months after buffs. They aren't consistent with how quickly the follow-up on changes. With that being said, it is perfectly fair-game to point that out to gypsylord, because his definition of follow-up may be 3 months from now, or maybe its on the next PBE patch, or even the next patch to go live. And because there is no guarantee for it to be *any* of those, the point of follow-up times being trash still stands.

Riot have recently changed this. Virtually every nerf this season has been followed up if it affects a champion too much. Veigar got further work (perhaps he is not done yet), Kassadin got work, I think Leblanc got more work done, although that may have been at the end of last season. 
This is always done after a few patches - the changes are allowed to settle first. This is also true for nerfing stronger champions. They are taking longer to nerf them, possibly to see if people find new ways around them. But they still get followed up!

Possibly the reason there is no guarantee of follow up is that most nerfs and buffs do as is intended. They lower or increase the power of a champion without destroying them or sending them to a permaban status. These don't need follow up.

Is there any nerf recently you think hasn't been followed up at all?

>Is there any nerf recently you think hasn't been followed up at all?

Elise was nerfed a while ago and has been left in a miserable state. Zilean was reworked when he was already terrible, and he's not any closer to being balanced. Azir's been allowed to rot. Kassadin got nerfed hard and has gotten extremely cautious compensation that hasn't made a significant difference. Syndra is apparently still competing for lowest winrate, so I'd bring that up too. I'm still not even remotely impressed that it took them around 9 months after Skarner's second rework to finally get him into a balanced state.

Riot hasn't done well on this. They've gotten better, but they still have a habit of hard nerfs followed by extremely overcautious buffing. I don't buy that they need months to evaluate the impact of very tiny buffs. They have a gigantic amount of room to improve here. I'll give them credit for not actively trying to Olaf champions anymore, but they still do leave champions hanging more often than is acceptable.

And Kassadin is doing wonders in competitive play - the buff to him was enough for them. Any more would be overkill

Syndra... According to champion.gg Syndra's win rate is 46.59%. It was about 46% before the nerfs as well. 

I would say that they do need a long time to analyse the impacts of small buffs. A champion is nerfed because it is a problem. Even small nerfs can affect a champion a large amount. Small buffs can also affect a champion a large amount, so should be treated with care - reintroducing problems is not the way to go.

Riot's history in these matters isn't great. Riot's recent history is much better. There is little reason now to feel they are going to leave champions "gutted" - they have changed their habits now.

Zilean is still terrible, as is Veigar. So is Trist, for that matter. all these champs have middling-to-low winrates; while Trist is far more popular than Veig or Zil, she makes up for it by having the worst winrate of any ADC in the game.

Riot really needs to fix those champs. I am not looking forward to the Poppy remake at this point.
